headline: I Read VF's Margot Robbie Profile And Have No Idea What The Words Mean
short descr: She's the latest female celeb subjected to painfully bad descriptions of her sex appeal.
image_caption(s): Margot Robbie, a woman who is beautiful but definitely "not in that otherwordly catwalk way."
article: It is a truth universally acknowledged that a woman in want of a Vanity Fair (or Esquire or Vogue) profile must be subjected to ham-fisted musings about her brand of beauty by a male writer. Take the opening paragraph of today‚Äôs lengthy Vanity Fair feature on actress Margot Robbie:She is 26 and beautiful, not in that otherwordly catwalk way but in a minor knock-around key, a blue mood, a slow dance. She is blonde but dark at the roots. She is tall but only with the help of certain shoes. She can be sexy and composed even while naked but only in character. As I said, she is from Australia. To understand her, you should think about what that means.If you‚Äôre reading those sentences and thinking, hmmm, I know what those words mean separately but I don‚Äôt understand them strung together in that order, you‚Äôre not alone. Vanity Fair‚Äôs Rich Cohen is just one in a long line of male writers who seemingly become truly befuddled when confronted with the conventional beauty of a famous woman ‚Äï and subsequently take it upon themselves to ‚Äúfigure her out.‚ÄùCohen‚Äôs profile traces Robbie‚Äôs path to Hollywood fame from Aussie soaps and looks forward to her role as Harley Quinn in the upcoming ‚ÄúSuicide Squad.‚Äù But those stories are obscured by descriptions of Robbie ‚Äúwander[ing] through the room like a second-semester freshman,‚Äù and the way her hair fell ‚Äúaround those painfully blue eyes.‚Äù Six paragraphs in, we get a mention of her ‚Äúambition‚Äù but only in the context of how it was ‚Äúmasked‚Äù by her ‚Äúbeauty and speed of ascent‚Äù into fame.Everyone wants to read a celebrity profile with a little color ‚Äï after all, these pieces are meant to give us some insight into who these famous humans actually are beyond the glamorous Instagrams and publicity-driven soundbites. But what does a writer‚Äôs lust for an actress‚Äô ‚Äúpainfully blue eyes‚Äù really tell us about that actress?The thing is, we know what Margot Robbie looks like! She stars in movies! She is photographed frequently! Those photographs appear on the covers of magazines ‚Äï like Vanity Fair!Flowery, borderline skeezy descriptors about the looks of female celebs have practically become de rigueur for these types of long-form profiles ‚Äï Sky Ferreira ‚Äúlooks like a dirtier Madonna‚Äù with ‚Äúkiller tits‚Äù (LA Weekly), Megan Fox is ‚Äúa screen saver on a teenage boy‚Äôs laptop, a middle-aged lawyer‚Äôs shower fantasy‚Äù (Esquire), Sofia Vergara has ‚ÄúColombian curves‚Äù (also Esquire). And yet, it‚Äôs something we rarely see employed when exploring the lives and psyches of famous men.As a thought experiment, writer and editor Donna Dickens swapped out Alexander Skarsgard‚Äôs name for Robbie‚Äôs.‚ÄúYep. Still creepy,‚Äù she tweeted. Famous women are expected to be beautiful at a bare minimum. When a female celebrity is young, that beauty is a puzzle to be solved by the men who gape at it. When she ages, it‚Äôs something she has lost, or worse, something she has attempted to hold onto by other means, in which case we accuse her of losing herself. (See: Renee Zellweger.)So, major magazines who commission these celebrity profiles: Next time you have the opportunity to dive into the life of a fascinating famous women, hire a writer who cares to see past the subject‚Äôs eyes.

headline: Major LGBT Rights Group Condemns Harvard Policy On Final Clubs
short descr: Campus Pride says students should have the right to join the influential single-sex organizations.
image_caption(s): New rules at Harvard aim to force Final Clubs to go co-ed or shut down entirely.
article: Campus Pride, one of the most prominent groups advocating for LGBT college students, is joining national fraternity and sorority groups in opposing a new policy at Harvard University that threatens the Ivy League school‚Äôs elite final clubs. Harvard announced a new rule in May meant to discourage students from joining unrecognized single-gender final clubs and Greek organizations. Students who join such groups cannot participate in leadership positions on campus, including on athletic teams, or be endorsed by the college for elite fellowships such as the Rhodes and Marshall scholarships. The move is intended to force the final clubs to either go co-ed or close their off campus operations.The clubs, which are prominent in the university‚Äôs social scene, operate much like fraternities or sororities. Although they are not not affiliated with most of the groups affected, national fraternity and sorority organizations condemned Harvard‚Äôs new policy as unfairly punishing undergraduates. About 1 in 10 graduating Harvard seniors belongs to a final club, unofficial estimates show; club members are also more likely to be white, straight and come from a wealthy background than the rest of the student body. Harvard took aim at the clubs following a survey that identified a correlation between membership in the groups and the risk of sexual assault. But Campus Pride is now defending their right to exist. ‚ÄúHarvard‚Äôs policy will not fix the serious campus problems of sexual assault or discrimination ‚Äï much less classism and racism. It will only drive them further underground,‚Äù Shane Windmeyer, the group‚Äôs executive director, said in a statement on Wednesday.‚ÄúBlocking access or restricting rights is never the answer to complex issues,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúInstead, we encourage Harvard to reconsider its policy and take a more complex, strategic ownership and responsibility in directly addressing the concerns at heart by all its student populations.‚ÄùAfter the policy change in May, more than 200 women protested against the attack on all-female final clubs. Shortly after, a former dean of the college argued the change was foolish and several professors prepared a resolution opposing the new rules.As a private school, Harvard can legally restrict what groups students join. But many of the policy‚Äôs critics say it violates the principle of free association, on par with blacklisting Communists. Trans students may prefer to join a single-sex club that matches their gender identity, Windmeyer argued, and Harvard should not take away their ability to do so.‚ÄúFor some trans and LGB young people, there is great value, affirmation and personal growth from being part of a single-gendered brotherhood or sisterhood,‚Äù Windmeyer said. ‚ÄúFor this reason, we strive to protect student rights to join any organization, including fraternities and sororities.‚ÄùHarvard did not respond to a request for comment. ______Tyler Kingkade covers higher education and is based in New York. You can contact him at tyler.kingkade@huffingtonpost.com, or find him on Twitter: @tylerkingkade.

headline: Roger Ailes Accused Of Sexism In The Workplace? The Record Is Long.
short descr: Gretchen Carlson is not the first to speak out against the Fox News chief.
image_caption(s): Fox News Chairman Roger Ailes has a well-recorded history of facing sexual assault allegations.
article: Long before Gretchen Carlson filed her incendiary lawsuit against Fox News Chairman Roger Ailes, plenty of women had come forward with their own memories of his sexism and sexual harassment. The former ‚ÄúFox & Friends‚Äù co-host alleges that Ailes fired her for rejecting a sexual relationship with him. Similar stories echo through Gabriel Sherman‚Äôs 2014 biography of the media magnate, titled The Loudest Voice in the Room.When television producer Randi Harrison interviewed with Ailes for a job at NBC in the 1980s, she said he offered her an extra hundred dollars a week if she agreed to have sex with him whenever he wanted, according to Sherman. Ailes, then president of CNBC, also reportedly made a pass at producer Shelley Ross while interviewing her for a job. She accepted the position after he apologized. Ailes later called her a ‚Äúmilitant feminist‚Äù when asked about the interview. People on set with Ailes recalled him demanding that on-air female personalities show more skin. One unnamed Fox News senior executive told Sherman that Ailes wanted ‚ÄúCrier Report‚Äù host Catherine Crier to stop wearing pantsuits and start showing off her legs, as Ailes had bought her a glass desk explicitly for that purpose. Fox News anchor Bob Sellers told Sherman that he once heard Ailes make similar comments about co-anchor Kiran Chetry when a laptop was blocking her legs from view.Fox News has dismissed Sherman‚Äôs book, claiming it was ‚Äúnever fact-checked with Fox News.‚Äù But you don‚Äôt have to rely on his book alone. Ailes has been open about sexualizing his female employees.He told The Associated Press in 2011 that he hired former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin ‚Äúbecause she was hot and got ratings.‚ÄùIn an interview the same year with Esquire, Ailes bragged about transforming Amy Kellogg from a woman with ‚Äúglasses or something,‚Äù ‚Äúthe wrong hair,‚Äù ‚Äúno makeup‚Äù and ‚Äúfunny clothes‚Äù into an acceptable on-screen reporter:‚ÄúI saw through all of it and I said, ‚ÄòAmy, you‚Äôre very attractive. Do you mind me sending you down to makeup? Let‚Äôs see if we can do a little work with you.‚Äô And she said, ‚ÄòNo, not at all.‚Äô Now she‚Äôs a great, terrific foreign correspondent for us.‚ÄùIf women don‚Äôt measure up to Ailes‚Äô expectations of beauty, he has made it known ‚Äï sometimes publicly. In a 1994 radio interview, he referred to two of his female employees, ‚ÄúEqual Time‚Äù hosts Mary Matalin and Jane Wallace, as the type of ‚Äúgirls‚Äù you wouldn‚Äôt pay attention to in a bar. An executive also recalled Ailes suggesting that ‚ÄúThe Five‚Äù co-host Andrea Tantaros was pretty but likely ineffective when she worked as a political consultant and that it ‚Äúmust not have been a good year‚Äù when Carlson was crowned Miss America.Fox News‚Äô women problems aren‚Äôt confined to Ailes. In 2004, host Bill O‚ÄôReilly settled out of court after one of his female employees allegedly recorded him sexually harassing her. And the network has repeatedly run segments defending cat-calling and critiquing women‚Äôs clothing choices.‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need a full trial to know that Fox News, as an institution, is ideologically geared towards minimizing, defending, and even promoting sexual harassment and the objectification of women,‚Äù Salon writer Amanda Marcotte wrote on Wednesday. ‚ÄúUnder Ailes‚Äô leadership, Fox News has put a premium on protecting a man‚Äôs ‚Äòright‚Äô to harass and demean women.‚ÄùIn the hours since Carlson‚Äôs lawsuit was announced, ‚Äúat least ten‚Äù other women have contacted the law firm representing her to speak about Ailes‚Äô treatment, a spokesman for the firm told CNN.Fox News‚Äô parent company has announced both its confidence in Ailes and its decision to begin an internal review.

headline: Feds Move To Block North Carolina From Enforcing 'Bathroom Bill'
short descr: The Department of Justice called the anti-trans law "state-sanctioned discrimination."
image_caption(s): The federal government has countersued North Carolina to halt enforcement of parts of House Bill 2, which dictates which bathrooms transgender individuals can use.
article: The U.S. Department of Justice has asked a federal judge to block North Carolina from enforcing parts of H.B.2, the controversial law requiring people to use public bathrooms corresponding to the sex on their birth certificate.‚ÄúH.B. 2 denies transgender people access to sex-segregated bathrooms and changing rooms consistent with their gender identity unless they can produce an amended birth certificate,‚Äù wrote lawyers for the department in the motion, filed late Tuesday, which contends that enforcement of the law violates federal civil rights statutes.The voluminous filing ‚Äï which was accompanied by dozens of exhibits and declarations from experts and trans people affected by the law ‚Äï is the latest in the federal government‚Äôs legal pushback against North Carolina, which began with a stern letter from DOJ to Gov. Pat McCrory (R) in May.H.B. 2 has also sparked a number of competing lawsuits, all of which will probably take years to resolve. DOJ, in its Tuesday filing, asserted that the interests North Carolina and its agencies have pushed in following through with the so-called bathroom bill ‚Äï including concerns for privacy and protection against sexual predators ‚Äï ‚Äúare factually baseless and legally insufficient to justify this discrimination.‚Äù ‚ÄúAs the record shows, transgender people in North Carolina have long used bathrooms consistent with their gender identity in private facilities and, before H.B. 2, in public facilities, without precipitating criminal conduct or widespread complaints about the invasion of privacy,‚Äù the lawyers wrote.‚ÄùH.B. 2 is not merely a solution to a non-existent problem; it is state-sanctioned discrimination that is inflicting immediate and significant harm on transgender individuals,‚Äù they added.The battle over H.B. 2 is seen as the latest frontier in the ongoing struggle over strengthening rights and protections for LGBT people, which scored its biggest win yet last year when the Supreme Court recognized that gay couples have a constitutional right to marry.But certain states and supporters of the bathroom bill also regard the fight as the Obama administration‚Äôs newest push for federal agencies ‚Äï such as the Department of Education and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ‚Äï to adopt an aggressive reading of anti-discrimination laws, which forbid discrimination on the basis of sex but don‚Äôt squarely address transgender discrimination.To that end, DOJ pointed in its Tuesday filing to a watershed ruling that agreed with the federal government‚Äôs reading of the ‚Äúsex‚Äù provision of Title IX, one of the laws at issue in the litigation, as encompassing discrimination against trans individuals. That ruling came from the federal appeals court that covers North Carolina.The department said that the ‚Äúcontrolling logic of that decision‚Äù and other rulings on the proper meaning of sex discrimination mean the federal government will likely win its challenge against H.B. 2.Whether the federal judge in this particular case agrees will be known soon. In the meantime, the same issues are coming to a head elsewhere in the country.On Wednesday, Texas and 12 other states filed their own motion ‚Äï in another federal court ‚Äï asking a judge to block the federal government from using civil rights laws to protect trans individuals.

headline: Democrats Were Never All That Concerned About The Clinton Email Scandal
short descr: Polls show that Democratic voters are largely unaffected by the investigation.
image_caption(s): Hillary Clinton attends a campaign rally in Charlotte, North Carolina, on Tuesday, the same day the FBI announced it would not recommend charges against her over her email practices as secretary of state.
article: Despite belief that Hillary Clinton's email scandal would be calamitous for her presidential prospects, polling suggests that Democratic voters' perception of Clinton has not been significantly impacted. The incident instead seems to register most saliently with Republican voters.Over half of all voters considered Clinton‚Äôs use of a private email address on a personal server while secretary of state ‚Äúunethical,‚Äù according to a Morning Consult poll. When the data is broken down by party, however, only 36 percent of Democrats called it ‚Äúunethical,‚Äù compared to an overwhelming 85 percent of Republicans. According to the same poll, only 24 percent of Democrats perceived the scandal as ‚Äúa major problem,‚Äù whereas over three-fourths of Republican voters did.This partisan divide naturally translates to voting tendencies. According to a poll by Suffolk University/USA Today conducted at the start of the investigation into Clinton‚Äôs private email server, 74 percent of Democrats said Clinton's actions did not matter in their vote, whereas 79 percent of Republicans said it did matter. Less than half of independent voters said that it impacted their vote.Polls also suggest that Democrats do not consider the email scandal a relevant indicator of Clinton's ability to govern effectively. According to a CNN/ORC poll conducted directly after the scandal broke, 46 percent of all voters said that the way Clinton handled her email while serving as secretary of state was an important indicator of her character and ability to serve as president, while 52 percent said it was not relevant. When the data is represented by party identification, however, the results are not nearly as split: three-fourths of Democrats said the incident was not ‚Äúrelevant to character,‚Äù whereas more than 6-in-10 Republicans said that it was.Although Clinton‚Äôs gradual decline in favorability ratings suggests that she failed to escape the FBI investigation unscathed, she still retains a 5-point lead against Trump, according to our HuffPost Pollster average. However, traces of the scandal are still reflected in public opinion.The words ‚Äúliar/dishonest‚Äù were ranked highest overall by voters to describe Clinton in a Suffolk/USA Today poll. But this characterization also had a partisan flavor. Among Republicans, these words were indisputably ranked highest -- 73 percent of GOP voters said this was an apt description, whereas only 8 percent of Democrats agreed. Among Democrats, however, the adjectives ranked as best describing Clinton were ‚Äúsmart/intelligent/knowledgeable.‚ÄùFBI Director James Comey announced Tuesday that ‚Äúno charges are appropriate" in Clinton's case, formally ending the bureau's investigation into her handling of classified emails on a private server. However, Republicans in Congress are now calling for new independent counsel to probe the former secretary of state's practices once more. The lasting impact of the email scandal on Clinton's public perception remains to be seen.
